title: I Iii
body: rporations. Instalments of the money subscribed for shares of stock, called for from the subscribers by the directors, from time to time as the company requires money, are called “assessments,” or, in Eng-landL, “calls.” water Co. v. Superior Court, 02 Cal. 47, 28 Pac. 54, 27 Am. St. Rep. 91; Spangler v. Railroad Co., 21 111. 278; Stew-art v. Publishing Co., 1 wash. St. 521, 20 Pac. 005

title: I, Ss N
body: iodical demands made by a mutual insurance company, under its charter and by-laws, upon the makers of premium notes, are also denominated “assessments." Hill v. Insurance Co., 129 Mich. 141, 88 N. W. 392

title: I W. A M
body: rights. A formal and emphatic leg-islative assertion and declaration of popular rights and liberties usually promulgated upon a change of government; particularly the stat-ute 1 W. A M. St. 2, c. 2. Also the summary of the rights and liberties of the people, or of the principles of constitutional law deemed es-sential and fundamental, contained in many of the American state constitutions.—Eason v. State, 11 Ark. 491; Atchison St. R. Co. v. Mis-souri Pac. R. Co.. 31 Kan. 661, 3 Pac. 284; orr v. Quimby, 54 N. H. 613

title: I H. Bi
body: ook. In mercantile law. A book in which an account of bilis of exchange and prom-issory notes, whether payable or receivable, is stated.—Bill-bead. A printed form on which merchants and traders make out thelr bills and render accounts to their customers.—Bill of lading. In common law. The written evidence of a contract for the carriage and delivery of goods sent by sea for a certain freight. Mason v. Lick barrow, 1 H. BI. 350. A written memorandum, given by the person in command of a merchant vessel, acknowledging the receipt on board the ship of certain specified goods, in good order or “apparent good order," which he undertakes, in consideration of the payment of freight, to deliver in like good order (dangers of tbe sea excepted) at a designated place to tbe consignee therein named or to his assigns. De-vato v. Barrels (D. C.) 20 Fed. 510; Gage v. Jaqueth. 1 Lans. (N. Y.) 210; The Delaware, 14 wall. 600, 20 L. Ed. 779. The term is often applied to a similar receipt and undertaking given by a carrier of goods by land. A bill of lading is an instrument in writing, signed by a carrier or his agent, describing the freight so as to identify it, stating the name of the con-signor, the terms of the contract for carriage, and agreeing or directing that the freight be delivered to the order or assigns of a specified person at a specified place. Civil Code Cal. $ 2126; Civil Code Dak. | 1229.—BUI of par-eels. A statement sent to the buyer of goods, along with the goods, exhibiting in detail tbe items composing the parcel and their several prices, to enable him to detect any mistake or omission; an invoice.—Bill of sale. In con-tracts. A written agreement under seal, by which one person assigns or transfers his right to or interest in goods and personal chattels to.another. An instrument by which, in par-ticular, the property in ships and vessels is conveyed. Putnam v. McDonald. 72 Vt. 4. 47 Atl. 159; Young v. Stone. 61 App. Div. 364, 70 N. Y. Supp. 558.—BUI parable. In a merchant’s accounts, all bills which he has ac-cepted, and promissory notes which he has made, are called “bills payable," and are entered in a ledger account under that name, and recorded in a book bearing the same title.—Bill reoeiv-ablo. In a merchant’s accounts, all notes, drafts, checks, etc., payable to him, or of which he is to receive the proceeds at a future date, are called “bills receivable." and are entered in a ledger-account under that name, and also noted in a book bearing the same title. State v. Robinson, 57 M<l- 501.—BUI rendered. A bill of items rendered by a creditor to his debtor; an “account rendered,” as distinguished from "an account stated.” Hill v. Hatch, 11 Me. 455. —Grand bill of sale. In English law. Tbe uame of an instrument used for tbe transfer of a ship while she is at sea. An expression which

title: I O U
body: A memorandum of debt, consisting of these letters, (“I owe you,”) a sum of money, and the debtor's signature, is termed an “I O U.” Kinney v. Flynn, 2 R. I. 329

title: Ibernagium
body: In old English law. The season for sowing winter corn. Also spelled “hibernagium” and “hybernagium

title: Ibidem
body: Lat in the same place; in the same book; on the same page, etc. Abbreviated to “ibid.” or “ib

title: Icona
body: An Image, figure, or representa-tlon of a thing. Du Cange

title: Ictus
body: In old English law. A stroke or blow from a club or stone; a bruise, contusion, or swelling produced by a blow from' a club or stone, as distinguished from “ploga,” (a wound.) Fleta, lib. 1, c. 41, | 3

title: Id Est
body: Lat That is. Commonly ab-breviated “i. e.”

title: Idem
body: Lat The same. According to Lord Coke, “idem" has two significations, se., idem syllable seu verbis, (the same in syllables or words,) and idem re et sensu, (the same in substance and in sense.) 10 Coke, 124a

title: Idem Per Idem
body: The same for tiie same. An illustration of a kind that really adds no additlonal element to the considera-Uon of the question

title: Idem Sonans
body: Sounding the same or alike; having the same sound. A term ap-plied to names which are substantially the same, though slightly varied In the spelling, as “Lawrence” and “Lawrance,” and the llke. 1 Cromp. & M. 806 ; 3 Chit. Gen. Pr. 171

title: Identification
body: Proof of identity; the prdvlng that a person, subject, or ar-tide before the court is the very same that he or It is alleged, charged, or reputed to be; as where a witness recognizes the prisoner at the bar as the same person whom lie saw committing the crime; or where handwrlt-ing, stolen goods, counterfeit coin, etc., are recognized as the same which once passed under the observation of the person identi-fylng them

title: Identitate Nominis
body: In English law. An ancient writ (now obsolete) which lay for one taken and arrested in any per-sonal action, and committed to prison, by mistake for another man of the same name, Fitzh. Nat Brev. 267

title: Identity
body: In tbo law of ovidenoo

title: Ideo
body: Lat. Therefore. Calvin

title: Ideo Consideratum Est
body: Lat. Therefore it is considered. These were the words used at the beginning ef the eutry of judgment in an action, when the forms were in Iatln. They are also used as a name for that portion of the record

title: Ides
body: A division of time among the Romans. In March, May, July, and october, the Ides were on the 15th of the month; in the remaining months, on the 13th. This method of reckoning is still retained in the chancery of Rome, and in the calendar of the breviary, wharton

title: Idiochira
body: Grseco-Lat. In the civil law. Ah instrument privately executed, as distinguished from such as were executed before a public officer. Cod. 8, 18, 11; Calvin

title: Idiocy
body: See Insanity

title: Idiot
body: A person who hns been withont understanding from hls nativity, nud w’hom the law, therefore, presumes never likely to attain any. Shelf. Lun. 2. See Insanity

title: Idiota
body: In' tbo civil law. An unlearned, illiterate, or simple person. Calvin. A private man; one not in office

title: Idiota Inquirendo, Writ De
body: This is the name of an old writ which directs the sheriff to inquire whether a man be an idiot or not. The Inquisition is to be made by a Jury of twelve men. Fitzh. Nat Brev. 2321 ..And, if the man were found an idiot, the profits of hls lands and the cos-tody of his person might be granted by Che

title: Idoneus
body: Lat. In the civil and com-mon law. Sufficient; competent; fit or proper; responsible; unimpeachable. Ido-neus homo, a responsible or solvent person; a good and lawful man. Sufficient; ade-quate; satisfactory. Idonea cautio, suffl-cient security

title: Idonietas
body: In old Engllsh law. AbU-ity or fitness, (of a parson.) Artie. Cleri, c. 13

title: Ii'Un Gia
body: In old Engllsh law. The fin-est whlte bread, formerly called “cocked bread." Blount

title: Iglise
body: L. Fr. A church. Kelham. Another form of “eglise.”

title: Ignis Judicium
body: Lat The old ju-dicial trial by fire. Blount

title: Ignitegium
body: In old English law. The curfew, or evenlng bell. Cowell. See Curfbw

title: Ignominy
body: Public dlsgrace; Infamy; reproach; dishonor. Ignominy is the op-posite of esteem, wolff, f 145. See Brown v. Kingsley, 38 Iowa, 220

title: Ignoramus
body: Lat. “we are igno-rant;” “We Ignore it.” Formerly the grand jury used to write thls word on bills of ln-dictment wben, after having heard the evi-dence, they thought the accusation against the prisoner was groundless, intimating that, though the facts might possibly be true, the truth did not appear to them; but now they usually wrlte in English the words “Not a true bill,” or “Not found,” if that is their verdict; but they are still said to ignore the bill. Brown

title: Ignorance
body: The want or absence of knowledge

title: Ignorantia
body: Lat. Ignorance; want of knowledge. Distinguished, from mistake, (error,) or wrong conception. Mackeld. Rom. Law, § 178; Dig. 22, 6. Divided by Lord Coke into ignorantia facti (ignorance of fact) and ignorantia juris, (ignorance of law.) And the former, he adds, is twofold.—lec-tionis et lingua, (Ignorance of reading and ignorance of language.) 2 Coke, 3b

title: Ignoratio Elenchi
body: Lat. A term of logic, sometimes applied to pleadings and to arguments on appeal, which signifies a mistake of the question, that is, the mistake of one who, failing to discern the real ques-tion which he is to meet and answer, ad-dresses his allegations or arguments to a collateral matter or somethlng beside the point. See Case upon tbe Statute for Dis-tribution, wythe (Va.) 309

title: Ignore
body: 1. To be ignorant of, or un-acquainted with

title: Ill Fame
body: Evil repute; notorious bad character. Houses of prostitution, gaming

title: Illata Et Invecta
body: Lat Thlngs brought Into the honse for use by the ten-ant were so called, and were liable to the jus hypothec# of Roman law, just as they are to tbe landlord’s rlght of distress at common law

title: Illegal
body: Not authorized by law; U-licit; unlawful; contrary to law

title: Illegitimacy
body: The condition before the law, or the social status, of a bastard; the state or condition of one whose parents were not intermarried at the tlme of hls birth. Miller v. Miller, 18 Hun (N. Y.) 509; Brown v. Belmarde, 3 Kan. 62

title: Illegitimate
body: That whlch is con-trary to law; It is usually applied to bas-tards, or children born out of lawful wed-lock

title: Illeviable
body: Not leviable; that can-not or ought not to be levled. Cowell

title: Illicenciatus
body: In old Engllsh law. Without license. Fleta, llb. 3, c. 5, i 12

title: Illicit
body: Not permitted or allowed; pro-hlbited; unlawful; as an illicit trade; <1

title: Illicite
body: Lat. Unlawfully. This word has a technical meanlng, and is requisite in an indictment where the act charged is un-lawful; as in the case of a riot 2 Hawk

title: Illicitum Collegium
body: Lat An il

title: Illiterate
body: Unlettered; ignorant; unlearned. Generally used of oue who can-not read and write. See In re Succession of Carroll, 28 La. Ann. 388

title: Illocable
body: Incapable of being placed eut or hired

title: Illud
body: Lat That

title: Illusion
body: In medical jurisprudence. An image or Impression in the mind, excited by some external object addressing itself to one or more of the senses, bnt which, in-stead of corresponding with the reality, is perverted, distorted, or wholly mistaken, the error being attributable to the imagination of the observer, not to any defect in the or-gans of sense. See Hallucination, and see "Delusion," under Insanity

title: Illustrious
body: The prefix to the title of a prince of the biood in England

title: Imagine
body: In English law. In cases ot treason the law makes it a crime to lmag-ine the death of the king. But, in order to complete the crime, this act of the mind must be demonstrated by some overt act. The terms “imagining” and “compassing’* are in this connection synonymous. 4 BL Comm. 78

title: Imaum
body: IMAM, or IMAUM. A Moham-medan prince having supreme spiritual as well as temporal power; a regular priest of the mosqu

title: Imbargo
body: An old form of “embargo,** (q. v.) SL 18 Car. II. c. 8

title: Imbasing Of Money
body: The act of

title: Imbecility
body: See Insanity

title: Imbezzle
body: An occasional or obsolete form of “embezzle,” (q. t

title: Imbladare
body: In old English law. To plant or sow graln. Bract fol. 176b

title: Imbracery
body: See Embracery

title: Imbrocus
body: A brook, gutter, or water-passage. CowelL

title: Imitation
body: The maklng of one thlng In the similitude or likeness of another; as, counterfeit coin is said to be made “ln lmita-tlon" of the genuine. An imitation of a trade-mark is that which so far resembles the genuine trade-mark as to be likely to induce the belief that it is genuine, whether by the use of words or letters similar in appearance or in sound, or by any sign, device, or other menns. Pen. Code N. Y. 1903, t 308; wagner v. Daly, 67 Hun, 477, 22 N. Y. Supp. 493; State v. Harris, 27 N. C. 294

title: Immaterial
body: Not material, essential, or necessary; not lmportant or pertinent; not decisive

title: Immediate
body: 1. Present; at once; without delay; not deferred by any Interval of time. In this sense, the word, without any very precise signification, denotes that action is or must be taken either Instantly or without any considerable loss of time

title: Immediately
body: “It is Impossible to lay down any hard and fast rule as to what is the meaning of the word ‘immediately’ in all cases. The words ‘forthwith’ and ‘im-mediately* have the same meaning. They are stronger than the expression *within a reasonable time,’ and Imply prompt, vigor-ous action, without auy delay, and whether there has been such action is a question of fact having regard to the circumstances of the particular case." Cockburn, C. J., in Reg. v. Justices of Berkshire, 4 Q. B. Div. 471

title: Immemorial
body: Beyond human mem-ory; time out of mind

title: Immeubles
body: Fr. These are, in French law, the immovables of English law. Thlngs are immeubles from any one of three causes: (3) From their own nature, e. g., lands and houses; (2) from their destina-tion, e. g., animals and instruments of agri-culture when supplied by the landlord; or (3) hy the object to which they are annexed, e. g., easements. Brown

title: Immigration
body: The coming Into a country of foreigners for purposes of per-manent residence. The correlative term “emigration” denotes the act of such persons in leaving thelr former country

title: Imminent Danger
body: In relation to homlclde in self-defense, this term means immediate danger, such as must be instantly met, such as cannot be guarded against by calling for the assistance of others or the protection of the law. U. S. v. outer-bridge, 27 Fed. Cas. 390; State v. west, 45 La. Ann. 14, 12 South. 7; State v. Smith, 43 or. 109, 71 Pac. 973. or, as otherwise defined, such an appearance of threatened and Impending Injury as would put a rea-sonable and prudent man to his instant de-fense. State v. Fontenot, 50 La. Ann. 537, 23 South. 634, 69 Am. St Rep. 455; Shorter ▼. People, 2 N. Y. 201, 51 Am. Dec. 286

title: Immiscere
body: Lat in the civil law. To mix or mingle with; to meddle with; to Join wlth. Calvin

title: Immittere
body: Lat. In tbe civU law. To put or let into, as a beam into a wall, fcalvin; Dlg. 50, 17, 242, 1

title: Immobilis
body: Let Immovable. Immobilia or res immobiles, immovable things, such as lands and buddings. Mackeld. Rom. Law, 1160

title: Immoral
body: Contrary to good morals; Inconsistent wlth the rules and principles of morality which regard men as living in a community, and which are necessary for the public welfare, order, and decency

title: Immorality
body: TY. That whlch to contra bonos mores. See Immoral

title: Immovables
body: In the clvll law. Property which, from its nature, destination, or the object to which it is applied, cannot move itself, or be removed

title: Immunity
body: An exemption from serv-ing in an office, or performing duties which the law generally requires other citizens to perform. Long v. Converse, 91 U. S. 113, 23 L. Ed. 233; Ex parte Levy, 43 Ark. 54, 51 Am. Rep. 550; Lonas v. State, 3 Heisk. (Tenn.) 306; Douglass v. Stephens, 1 Del. Ch. 476

title: Impaib
body: To weaken, diminish, or relax, or otherwlse affect In an lnjurlous manner. Davey v. 2Etna L. Ins. Co. (C. C.) 20 Fed. 482; State v. Carew, 13 Rich. Law (S. C.) 541, 91 Am. Dec. 245; Swinburne v. Mills, 17 wash. 611, 50 Pac. 489, 61 Am. St. Rep. 932

title: Impairing The Obligation Op Contracts
body: T8. For the meaning of this phrase in the constitution of the United States, see 2 Story, Const. §§ 1374-1399; 1 Kent, Comm. 413-422; Pom. Const Law; Black, Const Law (3d Ed.) p. 720 et seq

title: Impanel
body: In English praotioe. To

title: Imparcare
body: In old English law. To impound. Reg. orig. 92b

title: Impargamentum
body: The right of im-pounding cattle

title: Imparl
body: To have license to settle a litigation amicably; to obtain delay for ad-Justment

title: Imparlance
body: In early practice, imparlance meant time given to either of the parties to an action to answer the pleading of the other. It thus amounted to a continuance of the action to a further day. Literally the term signified leave given to the parties to talk together; i. e., with a view to settling their differences amicably. But in modern practice it denotes a time given to the defendant to plead

title: Imparsonee
body: L. Fr. In ecdeslas-tical law. one who is Inducted and in possession of a benefice. Parson lmparsonee, (persona impersonata.) Cowell; Dyer, 40

title: Impatronization
body: In ecclesiastical law. The act of putting Into full possession of a benefice

title: Impeach
body: To accuse; to charge a liability upon; to sue

title: Impeachment
body: A criminal proceed-lng against a public officer, before a quasi political court, instituted by a written accu-sation called “articles of impeachment;” for example, a written accusation by the house of representatives of the United States to

title: Impechiare
body: To Impeach, to accuse, or prosecute for felony or treason

title: Impediens
body: In old practice, one who hinders; an lmpedlent. The defendant or deforciant in a flne was sometimes so called. Cowell; Blount

title: Impedimento
body: In Spanish law. A prohibition to contract marriage, established by law between certain persons

title: Impediments
body: Disabilities, or hin-drances to the making of contracts, snch as coverture, infancy, want of reason, etc

title: Impeditor
body: In old English law. A disturber in the action of quare impedit. St Marlb. c. 12

title: Impens.X
body: Lat. In the civil law. Ex-penses; outlays. Mackeld. Rom. Law, S 168; Calvin. Divided into necessary, (necessaries,) useful, (utiles,) and tasteful or orna-mental, (voluptuaries.) Dig. 50, 16, 79. See Id. 25, 1

title: Imperative
body: See Dibectobt

title: Imperfect
body: As used in various legal compound terms, this word means defective or incomplete; wanting in some legal or formal requisite; wanting in legal sanction or effectiveness; as in speaking of imperfect “obligations," “ownership," “rights," “title," “usufruct,” or “war.” See those nouns

title: Imperitia
body: Lat. Unskillfulness; want of skill

title: Imperium
body: The right to command, which includes the right to employ the force of the state to enforce the laws. Thls is one of the principal attributes of the power ot the executive. 1 Toullier, no. 58

title: Impertinence
body: Irrelevancy; the fault of not properly pertaining to the issue or proceeding. The introduction of any mat-ters into a bill, answer, or other pleading or proceeding in a suit, which are not properly before the court for decision, at any particular stage of the suit Story, Eq. PL

title: Impertinent
body: In equity pleading

title: Impescare
body: In old records. To im* peach or accuse. Impescatus, Impeached. Blount

title: Impetrare
body: In old English practice. To obtain by request, as a writ or privilege. Bract fols. 57, 172b. This appllcatlon of the word seems to be derlved from the clvll law. Calvin

title: Impetration
body: In old English law. The obtaining anything by petition or en-treaty. Particularly, the obtaining of a benefice from Rome by solicitation, which benefice belonged to the disposal of the king er other lay patron, webster; CowelL

title: Imfier
body: Umpire, (q. v

title: Impierment
body: Impairing or prejudle-Ing. Jacob

title: Impignorata
body: Pledged; given in pledge, (pignori data;) mortgaged. A term applied in Bracton to land. Bract, fol. 20

title: Impignoration
body: The act of pawn-lng or putting to pledge

title: Implacitare
body: Let To Implead; to sue

title: Implead
body: In practice. To sue or prosecute by due course of law. People ▼. Clarke, 0 N. Y. 368

title: Impleaded
body: Sued or prosecuted; used particularly in the titles of causes where there are several defendants; as “A. B., im-pleaded with C. D.”

title: Implements
body: Snch things as are used or employed for a trade, or furniture of a house. Coolidge ▼. Choate, 11 Metc. (Mass.) 82

title: Implicata
body: A term used in mercan-tile law, derived from.the Italian. In order to avoid the risk of making fruitless voyages, merchants have been in the habit of receiv-ing small adventures, on freight, at so much per cent, to which they are entitled at all events, even if the adventure be lost; and this is called “implicata.” wharton

title: Implication
body: Intendment or infer-ence, as dlstlngulshed from the actual expression of a thlng In words. In a wlll, an estate may pass by mere implication, without any express words to direct Its course. 2 BL Comm. 381

title: Implied
body: This word is nsed in law as contrasted with “express;” i. where the Intention in regard to the subject-matter is not manifested by explicit and direct words, but is gathered by implication or necessary deduction from the circumstances, the gen-eral language, or the conduct of the parties

title: Importation
body: The act of bringing goods and merchandise Into a country from a foreign country

title: Imports
body: Importations; goods or other property imported or brought into the country from a foreign country

title: Imfortunity
body: Pressing solicitation; urgent request; application for a claim or favor which is urged with troublesome frequency or pertinacity, webster

title: Imposition
body: An Impost; tax; contribution. Paterson v. Society, 24 N. J. Law, 400; Singer Mfg. Co. v. Heppenheimer, 58

title: Impossible Contracts
body: An impossible contract is one which the law will not hold binding upon the parties, because of the natural or legal impossibility of the performance by one party of that which is the consideration for the promise of the other. 7 wait, Act ft Def. 124

title: Imfosts
body: Taxes, duties, or impositions. A duty on imported goods or merchandise. Story, Const § 949. And see Norris v. Bos-ton, 4 Metc. (Mass.) 296; Pacific Ins. Co. v. Soule, 7 wait 435, 19 L. Ed. 93; woodruff v. Parham, 8 wall. 131, 19 L Ed. 382; Dooley v. U. S., 183 U. S. 151, 22 Sup. Ct 62, 43 L. Ed. 128; Passenger Cases, 7 How. 407, 12 L. Ed. 702

title: Imfotence
body: In medical jurisprudence. The incapacity for copulation or propagating the species. Properly used of the male; but it has also been used synonymously with “sterility.” Griffeth v. Griff-eth, 162 111. 368, 44 N. E. 820; Payne v. Payne, 46 Mlnn. 467, 49 N. W. 230, 24 Am. St Rep. 240; Kempf v. Kempf, 34 Mo. 213

title: Imp O Tent I Am, Property Propter
body: A qualified property, which may subsist In animals ferae natura on account of thelr inability, as where hawks, herons, or other birds build In a person's trees, or conies, etc., make thelr nests or burrows In a person’s land, and have yonng there, such person has a qualified property in them till they can fly or run away, and then snch property expires. 2 Steph. Comm. (7th Ed.)

title: Impound
body: To shut up stray animals or distrained goods in a pound. Thomas v. Harries, 1 Man. & G. 703; Goodsell v. Dunning, 34 Conn. 257; Howard v. Bartlett, 70 VL 314. 40 Atl. 825

title: Imprescriptibility
body: The state or quality of being incapable of prescription; not of such a character that a right to it can be gained by prescription

title: Imprescriptible Rights
body: Such rights as a person may use or not. at pleasure, since they cannot be lost to him by

title: Impression
body: A “case of the first im-pression” is one without a precedent; one presenting a wholly new state of facts; one Involving a question never before determined

title: Impressment
body: A power possessed by the English crown of taking persons or property to aid in the defense of the country, with or without the consent of the persons concerned. It is usually exercised to obtain hands for the royal ships in time of war, by taking seamen engaged in merchant vessels, (1 Bl. Comm. 420; Maud & P. Shipp. 123:) but in former times impressment of merchant ships was also practiced. The admiralty issues protections against impress-ment in certain cases, either under statutes passed in favor of certain callings (e. g., persons employed in the Greenland fisheries) or voluntarily. Sweet

title: Imprest Money
body: Money pald on enlisting or lmpresslng soldiers or sailors

title: Impretiabilis
body: Lat. Beyond price; invaluable

title: Imprimatur
body: Lat. Let it be prlnted. A license or allowance, granted by the constituted authorities, giving permisslon to print and publish a book. This allowance wns formerly necessary, in England, before any book could lawfully be printed, and in some other countries is still required

title: Imprimere
body: To press upon; to impress or press; to imprint or print

title: Imprimery
body: In some of the ancient English statutes this word is used to signify a printing-office, the art of printing, a print or impression

title: Imprimis
body: Lat in the first place; first of all

title: Imprison
body: To put in a prison; to put in a place of confinement

title: Imprisonment
body: The act of putting or confining a man in prison; the restraint of a man’s personal liberty; coercion exer-cised upon a person to prevent the free exer-clse of his powers of locomotion. State v. Shaw, 73 Vt 149, 50 Atl. 863; In re Langs-low, 167 N. Y. 314, 60 N. E. 590; In re Langan (C. C.) 123 Fed. 134; Steere v. Field, 22 Fed. Cas. 1221

title: Impristi
body: Adherents; followers. Those who slde wlth or take the part of another, either in his defense or otherwise

title: Improbation
body: In Scotch law. An action brought for the purpose -of having some instrument declared false and forged. 1 Forb. Inst pt 4, p. 161. The verb “lm-prove” (q. v.) was used in the same sense

title: Improper
body: Not suitable; unfit; not suited to the character, time, and place. Palmer v. Concord, 48 N. H. 211, 97 Am. Dec. 605. wrongful. 53 Law J. P. D. 65

title: Impropriate Rector
body: In ecclesiastical law. Commonly signifies a lay rector as opposed to a spiritual rector; just as irn-propriate tithes are tithes in the hands of a lay owner, as opposed to approprlate tithes, which are tithes in the hands of a spiritual owner. Brown

title: Impropriation
body: In ecclesiastical law. The annexing an ecclesiastical bene-flee to the use of a lay person, whether indl-vidual or corporate, In the same way as appropriation i§ the annexing of any such bene-flce to the proper and perpetual use-of some splritual corporation, whether sole or aggre-gate, to enjoy forever. Brown

title: Improve
body: In Scotch law. To dls-prove; to invalidate or Impeach; to prove false or forged. 1 Forb. InsL pt 4, p. 162

title: Improved
body: Improved land is such as has been reclaimed, is used for the purpose of husbandry, and is cultivated as such, whether the appropriation is for tillage, meadow, or pasture. “Improve" is synonymous with “cultivate.” Clark v. Phelps, 4 Cow. (N. Y.) 190

title: Improvement
body: A valuable addition made to property (usually real estate) or an amelioration in its condition, amounting to more than mere repairs or replacement of waste, costing labor or capltal, and Intended to enhance lts value and utility or to adapt it for new or further purposes. Spencer v. Tobey, 22 Barb. (N. Y.) 269; Allen v. McKay, 120 Cal. 332, 62 Pac. 828; Simpson v. Robinson, 37 Ark. 132

title: Improvements
body: A term used in leas-es, of doubtful meaning. It would seem to apply principally to buildings, though generally it extends to the amelioration of every description of property, whether real or personal; but, when contained in any document, its meaning is generally explained by other words. 1 Chlt Gen. Pr. 174

title: Impruiare
body: In old records. To im-prove land. Impruiamcntum, tbe improve-ment so made of it Cowell

title: Impulse
body: As to “irresistible” or "un-con trollable” impulse, see Insanitt

title: Impunity
body: Exemption or protection from penalty or punishment Dillon v. Rogers, 36 Tex. 153

title: Imputatio
body: LaL In the civil law. Legal llabillty

title: Imputation Of Payment
body: In the

title: Imputed
body: As used in legal phrases, thls word means attributed vicariously; that is, an act, fact, or quality is said to be “imput-ed” to a person when it is ascribed or charged to him, not because he is personally cognizant of it or responsible for it, but because another person is, over whom he has control or for whose acts or knowledge he is re-sponsible

title: In Agtion
body: Attainable or recoverable by actlon; not in possesslon. A term ap-plied to property of which a party has not the possession, but only a rlght to recover it by action. Things in action are rights of personal things, whicb nevertheless are not in possession. See Chose in Action

title: In Adversum
body: Against an adverse, unwilling, or resisting party. “A decree not by consent, but in adversum." 3 Story, 818

title: In Ajqua Manu
body: In equal hand. Fle-te, lib. 3, c. 14, f 2

title: In Jequali Manu
body: In equal hand; held equally or indifferently between two parties, where an instrument was deposit-ed by the parties to it in tbe hands of a third

title: In Aueno Solo
body: In another's land

title: In Alio Loco
body: In another place

title: In Aperta Luce
body: In open daylight; in tbe day-time. 9 Coke, 65b

title: In Apicibus Juris
body: Among the sub-tleties or extreme doctrines of the law. 1 Eames, Eq. 190. See Apex Juris

title: In Arbitrium Judicis
body: At the

title: In Arcta Et Salva Custodia
body: In

title: In Artigulo
body: In a moment; imme-diately. Cod. 1, 64, 2

title: In Articulo Mortis
body: In the article of death; at the point of death. Jack-son ▼. Vredenbergh, 1 Johns. (N. Y.) 159

title: In Autre Droit
body: L. Fr. In anoth-er’s right As representing another. An ex

title: In Banco
body: In hank; in the bench. A term applied to proceedings in the court in bank, as distinguished from proceedings at nisi prius. Also, in the English court of common beuch

title: In Being
body: In existence or life at a giv-en moment of time, as, in the phrase “life or lives in being” in the rule against per-petnities. An unborn child may, in some circumstances be considered as “in being.” Phillips v. Herron, 55 ohio St. 478, 45 N, E. 720; Hone v. Van Schalck, 3 Barb. Ch. (N. Y.) 509

title: In Blank
body: A ten., applied to the ln-dorseinent of a bill or note where it consists merely of the lndorser's name, without restriction to any particular Indorsee. 2 Steph. Comm. 164

title: In Bonis
body: Among the goods or property; In actual possession. Inst. 4, 2, 2. In bonis defunctl, among the goods of the deceased

title: In Bulk
body: As a whole; as an entirety, without division into items or physical sep-aration in packages or parcels. Standard 011 Co. v. Com., 119 Ky. 75, 82 8. W. 1022; Fitz Henry v. Munter, 33 wash. 629, 74 Pac. 1003; State ▼. Smith. 114 Mo. 180, 21 S. W. 493

title: In Camera
body: In chambers; in private. A cause is said to be heard in camera either when the hearing is had before the Judge in his private room or when all spectators are excluded from the court-room

title: In Capita
body: To the heads; by heads or polls. Persons succeed to nn inheritance in capita when they individually take equal shares. So challenges to individual jurors are challenges in capita, as dlstlngulshed from challenges to the array

title: In Capite
body: In chief. 2 Bl. Comm. 60. Tenure in capite was a holding directly from the king

title: In Casu Proviso
body: In a (or the) case provided. In tali casu editum et provisum, in such case made and provided. Townsh. Pl. 1(54. 165

title: In Causa
body: In the cause, as distlnguisb-ed from in initialibus, (q. v.) A term in Scotch practice. 1 Brown, Ch. 252

title: In Chief
body: Principal; primary; directly obtained. A term applled to the evidence obtained from a witness upon hls examina-tion in court by the party producing him

title: In Commendam
body: In commendatlon; as a commended llvlng. 1 BL Comm. 393. See COMMENDA

title: In Common
body: Shared in respect to title, nse, or enjoyment, without apportionment or division into individual parts; held by sever-al for the equal advantage, use, or enjoy-ment of all. See Hewit v. Jewell, 59 Iowa, 87, 12 N. W. 738; Chambers v. Harrington, 111 U. S. 350, 4 Sup. Ct. 428, 28 L. Ed. 452; walker v. Dunsbee, 88 Pa. 439

title: In Communi
body: In common. Fleta, lib. 8, c. 4, § 2

title: In Consideratione Inde
body: In con

title: In Consideratione Legis
body: In consideration or contemplation of law; in abey-ance. Dyer, 102b

title: In Consfectu Ejus
body: In hls sight or

title: In Continenti
body: Immediately; with-out any interval or Intermission. Calvin. Sometimes written as one word “incontinent

title: In Corpore
body: In body or substance; in a material thing or object

title: In Crastino
body: on the morrow. In crastino Animarum, on the morrow of All Souls. 1 Bl. Comm. 342

title: In Cujus Rei Testimonium
body: In

title: In Custodia Legis
body: In the custody or keeping of the law. 2 Steph. Conun. 74

title: In Delicto
body: In fault See In Pabi

title: In Diem
body: For a day; for the space of a day. Calvin

title: In Dominico
body: In demesne. In dominion suo ui de feodo, in hls demesne as of fee

title: In Dorso
body: on the back. 2 Bl. Comm. 468; 2 Steph. Comm. 164. In dorao reoordi, on the back of the record. 5 Coke, 45. Hence the English indorse, indorsement, etc

title: In Dubio
body: In doubt; in a state of un-certainty, or in a doubtful case

title: In Duplo
body: In double. Damna in du-plo, double damages. Fleta, llb. 4, c. 10, 8 1

title: In Eadem Causa
body: In the same state or condltion. Calvin

title: In Emulationem Vicini
body: In envy or hatred of a neighbor, where an act is

title: In Equity
body: In a court of equlty, as distinguished from a court of law; in the purview, consideration, or contemplation of equity; according to the doctrines of equity

title: In Esse
body: In being. Actually existing. Distinguished from in posse, which means "that which is not, but may be.” A child before birth is in posse; after birth, in esse

title: In Evidence
body: Included in the evidence already adduced. The “facts in evidence” are such as have already been proved in the canse

title: In Excambio
body: In exchange. Formal words in old deeds of exchange

title: In Exitu
body: In issue. De materia in exitu, of the matter in issue. 12 Mod. 372

title: In Extenso
body: In extension; at fall length; from beginning to end, leaving out nothing

title: In Extremis
body: In extremity; in the last' extremity; in the last illness. 2 Bl. Comm. 375, 500; Prince v. Hazleton, 20 Johns. (N. Y.) 502, 11 Am. Dec. 307. Agens in extremis, being in extremity. Bract, fol. 373b. Declarations in extremis, dying declarations. 1 Greenl. Ev. | 156; wilson v. Boerem, 15 Johns. (N. Y.) 286

title: In Facie Curiae
body: In the face of the court Dyer, 28

title: In Facie Ecclesls
body: In the face of the church. A term applied In the law of England to marriages, which are required to be solemnized in a parish church or public chapel, unless by dispensation or license. 1 Bl. Comm. 439; 2 Steph. Comm. 288, 289. Applied in Bracton to tiie old mode of conferring dower. Bract fol. 92; 2 Bl. Comm. 133

title: In Faciendo
body: In doing; in feasance; in the performance of an act 2 Story, Eq. Jur. | 1308

title: In Fact
body: Actual, real; as dlstlngulsh-ed from implied or inferred. Resulting from the acts of parties. Instead of from the act or intendment of law

title: In Facto
body: In fact; in deed. In faota dicit, in fact says. 1 Salk. 22, pl. L

title: In Favorem Libertatis
body: In fa

title: In Feodo
body: In fee. Bract fol. 207; Fleta, lib. 2, c. 64, $ 15. Seisitus in feodo, seised in fee. Fleta, lib. 3, c. 7, 11

title: In Fieri
body: In being made; in process of formation or development; hence, incomplete or inchoate. Legal proceedings are described as in fieri until judgment is entered

title: In Fine
body: Lat At the end. Used, in references, to indicate that the passage cited is at the end of a book, chapter, section, etc

title: In Forma Pauperis
body: In the character or manner of a pauper. Describes permission given to a poor person to sue without liability for costs

title: In Foro
body: In a (or the) forum, court, or tribunal

title: In Fraudem Creditorum
body: In

title: In Full
body: Relating to the whole or full amount; os a receipt in full. Complete; giving all details. Bard v. wood, 8 Metc. (Mass.) 75

title: In Full Life
body: Continuing in both physical and civil existence; that is, neither actually dead nor civiliter mortuus

title: In Futuro
body: In future; at a future time; the opposite of in prasenti. 2 BL Comm. 166, 175

title: In Generali Passagio
body: In the general passage; that is, on the journey to Palestine with the general company or body of Crusaders. This term was of frequent occurrence in the old law of essoins, as a means of accounting for the absence of the party, and was distinguished from simplex possagi-urn, which meant that he was performing a pilgrimage to the Holy Land alone

title: In Genere
body: In kind; in the same genus or class; the same in quantity and quality, but not individually the same. In the Roman law, things which may be given or restored in genere are distinguished from such as must be given or restored in specie; that is, identically. Mackeld. Rom. Law, | 16L

title: In Gremio Legis
body: In the bosom of the law; in the protection of the law; in abeyance. 1 Coke, 131a; T. Raym. 819

title: In Gross
body: In a large quantity or sura; without division or particulars;' by whole-sale. Green v. Taylor, 10 Fed. Cas. No. 1,126

title: In Hac Parte
body: In this behalf; on this side

title: In Hsbc Verba
body: In these words; in the same words

title: In Hoc
body: In this; in respect to this

title: In Hsdem Terminis
body: In the same terms. 9 East, 487

title: In Indtviduo
body: In the distinct, identical, or Individual form; in specie. Story, Bailm. | 97

title: In Infinitum
body: Infinitely; indefinitely. Imports Indefinite succession or continuance

title: In Initialibus
body: In the prellmlna-ries. A term in Scotch practice, applied to the preliminary examination of a witness as to the following points: whether he knows the parties, or bears ill will to either of them, or has recelved any reward or promise of reward for what he may say, or con lose or gain by the cause, or has been told by any person what to say. If the witness answer these questions satisfactorily, he is then examined in causa, in the cause. Bell, Dict “Evidence.”

title: In Xnitio
body: In or at the beginning. In initio litis, at the beginning, or in the first stage of the snit Bract fol. 400

title: In Integrum
body: To the original or for-mer state. Calvin

title: In Invidiam
body: To excite a prejudice

title: In Invitum
body: Against an unwilling party; against one not assenting. A term applied to proceedings against an adverse party, to which he does not consent

title: In Ipsis Faucibus
body: In the very throat or entrance. In ipsis faucibus of a port, actually entering a port 1 C. Rob. Adm. 233, 234

title: In Itinere
body: In eyre; on a journey or circuit. In old English law, the justices in itinere (or in eyre) were those who made a circuit through the kingdom once in seven years for the purposes of trying causes. 3 Bl. Comm. 58

title: In Judgment
body: In a court of justice; in a seat of judgment Lord Hale is called “one of the greatest and best men who ever sat in judgment" 1 East, 306

title: In Judicio
body: In Roman law. In the course of an actual trial; before a judge, (judex.) A cause, during its preparatory stages, conducted before the prtetor, was said to be in jure; in its second stage, after it had been sent to a judex tor trial, it was said to be in judicio

title: In Jure
body: In law; according to law. In the Roman practice, the procedure in an action was divided into two stages. The first was said to be in jure; it took place before the prsetor, and included the formal and Introductory part and the settlement of ques-ions of law. The second stage was committed to the judex, and comprised the In-vestigatlon and trial of the facts; this was said to be in judicio

title: In Jure Alterius
body: In another’s fight Hale, Anal. { 26

title: In Jure Proprio
body: In one’s own right. Hale, Anal. $ 26

title: In Jus Vocare
body: To call, cite, or summon to court Inst. 4, 16, 3; Calvin. In jus vocando, summoning to court 3 BL Comm. 279

title: In Kind
body: ND. In the same kind, class, or genus. A loan is returned “in kind” when not the identical article, but one corresponding and equivalent to it, is given to the lender. See In Genere

title: In Law
body: In the intendment, contem-plation, or inference of the law; Implied or Inferred by law; existing in law or by force of law. See In Fact

title: In Lecto Mortali
body: on the death

title: In Litem
body: For a suit; to the suit Greenl. Ev. § 348

title: In Loco
body: In place; In lieu; instead; in the place or stead. Townsh. Pl. 38

title: In Loco Parentis
body: In the place of a parent; instead of a parent; charged, factitiously, wlth a parent’s rights, duties, and

title: In Malam Partem
body: In a bad sense, so as to wear an evil appearance

title: In Medias Res
body: Into the heart of the subject, without preface or introduction

title: In Medio
body: Intermediate. A term applied, in Scotch practice, to a fund held he-tween parties litigant

title: In Mercy
body: To be In mercy is to be at the discretion of the king, lord, or judge in respect to the Imposltlon of a fine or other punishment

title: In Misericordia
body: The entry on the record where a party was in mercy was, “Ideo in misericordia,” etc. Sometimes “misericordia” means the being quit of all amercements

title: In Mitiori Sensu
body: In the milder sense; in the less aggravated acceptation. In actions of slander, it was formerly the rale that if the words alleged would admit of two constructions, they should be taken in the less injurious and defamatory sense, or in mitiori sensu

title: In Modum Assisje
body: In the manner or form of an assize. Bract fol. 183b. In modum juratas, in manner of a jnry. Id. fob 181b

title: In Mora
body: In default; literally, in delay. In the civil law, a borrower who omits

title: In Mortua Manu
body: Property owned by religions societies was said to be held in mortua manu, or in mortmain, since religions men were civiliter mortui. 1 Bl. Comm. 479; Tayl. Gloss

title: In Nomine Dei, Amen
body: In the name of God, Amen. A solemn lntroduction, anciently used in wills and many other lnstru-ments. The translation is often used In wills at the present day

title: In Notis
body: In the notes

title: In Nubibus
body: In the clouds; in abeyance; in custody of law. In nubibus, in mare, in terrA, vel in custodiA legis, in the air, sea, or earth, or in the custody of the law. Tayl. Gloss. In case of abeyance, the inheritance is figuratively said to rest in nu-bibus, or in gremio legis

title: In Nullius Bonis
body: Among the goods or property of no person; belonging to no person, as treasure-trove and wreck were anciently considered

title: In Nullo Est Erratum
body: In noth-lng is there error. The name of the common plea or joinder in error, denying the existence of error in the record or proceedings; which is in the nature of a demurrer, and at once refers the matter of law arlslng thereon to the Judgment of the court 2 Tidd, Pr. 1173; Booth v. Com., 7 Metc. (Mass.) 285, 287

title: In Omnibus
body: In all thlngs; on all points. “A case parallel in omnibus” 10 Mod. 104

title: In Pacato Solo
body: In a country which is at peace

title: In Pace Dei Et Regis
body: In the peace of God and the king. Fleta, lib. 1, c. 31, | 6 Formal words in old appeals of murder

title: In Pais
body: This phrase, as applied to a legal transaction, primarily means that it has taken place without legal proceedings. Thus a widow was said to make a request in pais for her dower when she simply applied to the heir without issuing a writ (Co. Litt. 32b.) So conveyances are divided into thoee by matter of record and those by mat

title: In Paper
body: A term formerly applied to the proceedings in a cause before the rec-ord was made up. 3 Bl. Comm. 406 ; 2 Bur-rows, 1098. Probably from the circumstance of the record being always on parchment The opposite of “on record." 1 Burrows, 322

title: In Pari Causa
body: In an equal cause. In a cause where the parties on each side have equal rights

title: In Pari Delicto
body: In equal fault; equally culpable or crlmlnal; in a case of equal fault or guilt. See Rozell v. Vansyckle, 11 wash. 79, 39 Pac. 270

title: In Pari Materia
body: Upon the same matter or subject. Statutes in pari materia are to construed together. United Society v. Eagle Bank, 7 Conn. 457; State v. Ger-hardt, 145 Ind. 439, 44 N. E. 469, 33 L. R. A. 313; People v. New York Cent Ry. Co., 25 Barb. (N. Y.) 291; Sales v. Barber Asphalt Pav. Co., 166 Mo. 671, 66 S. W. 979

title: In Patiendo
body: In suffering, permitting, or allowing

title: In Pectore Judicis
body: In the breast of the judge. Latch, ISO. A phrase applied to a judgment

title: In Pejorem Partem
body: In the worst

title: In Perpetuam Rei Memoriam
body: In perpetual memory of a matter; for pre-serving a record of a matter. Applied to depositions taken in order to preserve tho testimony of the deponent

title: In Perpetuum Rei Testimonium
body: In perpetual testimony of a matter

title: In Person
body: A party, plaintiff or defendant, who sues out a writ or other pro-cess, or appears to conduct his case in court himself, instead of through a solicitor or counsel, is said to act and appear in person

title: In Personam, In Rem
body: In the Ro-maa law, from which they are taken, the expressions “in rem” and “in personam” were always opposed to one another, an act or proceeding in personam being one done or directed against or with reference to a spe-clflc person, while an act or proceeding in rem was one done or directed with refer-ence to no specific person, and consequently against or with reference to all whom it might concern, or “ail the world.” The phrases were especially applied to actions; an actio in personam being the remedy where a claim against a specific person arose out of an obligation, whether ex contractu or ex maleficio, while an actio in rem was one brought for the assertion of a right of prop-erty, easement, status, etc., against one who denied or infringed it See InsL 4, 6, 1; Gaius, 4, 1, 1-10; 5 Sav. Syst. 13, et seq.; Dig. 2, 4, 7, 8; Id. 4, 2, 0, 1

title: In Pios Usus
body: For pious uses; for religious purposes. 2 Bl. Comm. 005

title: In Plage
body: In mining law, rock or min-eralized matter is “in place" when remain-lng as nature placed it, that is, unsevered from the circumjacent rock, or which is fixed solid and immovable in the form -of a vein or lode. See williams v. Gibson, 84 Ala. 228, 4 South. 350, 5 Am. St. Rep. 868 ; Ste-vens ▼. williams, 23 Fed. Cas. 44; Tabor ▼. Dealer, 23 Fed. Cas. 615; Leadville Co. v. Fitzgerald, 15 Fed. Cas. 99; Jones ▼. Pros-pect Mountain Tunnel Co., 21 Nev. 839, 81 Pac. 645

title: In Plena Vita
body: In full life. Yearb. P. 18 Hen. VI. 2

title: In Pleno Comitatu
body: In full conn-ty court 3 Bl. Comm. 36

title: In Pleno Lumine
body: In public; in common knowledge; in the light of day

title: In Posse
body: In possibility; not lu actual existence. See In Esse

title: In Potestate Parentis
body: In the power of a parent. Inst 1, 8, pr.; Id. 1, 9; 2 BL Comm. 498

title: In Prxmissorum Fidem
body: In con-firmation or attestation of the premises. A notarial phrase

title: In Xprjesenti
body: At the present time. 2 Bl. Comm. 166. Used in opposition to in futuro. See Van wyck ▼. Knevals, 106 U. 8. 860, 1 Sup. Ct 336, 27 Lu Ed. 201

title: In Prender
body: L. Fr. In taking. A term applied to such incorporeal heredi ta-ments as a party entitled to them was to take tor himself; such as common. 2 Steph. Oomm. 23; 3 Bl. Comm. 15

title: In Primis
body: In the first place. A phrase used in argument

title: In Principio
body: At the beginning

title: In Promptu
body: In readiness; at hand

title: In Propria Persona
body: In one's own proper person

title: In Be
body: In the affair; in the matter of. This is tbe usual method of entitling a Judi-clal proceeding in which there are not adver-sary parties, but merely some res concerning whlch judlcial actlon is to be taken, such as a bankrupt’s estate, an estate in the probate court, a proposed public highway, etc. It is also sometimes used as a designation of a proceeding where one party makes an appli-cation on his own behalf, but such proceed-ings are more usually entitled “Ex parte

title: In Rem
body: A technical terra used to des-lgnate proceedings or actions instituted against the thing, in contradistinction to personal actions, which are said to be in personam. See In Pebsonam

title: In Render
body: A thing is said to He in render when it must be rendered or given by the tenant; as rent It is said to lie in prender when it consists in the right In the lord or other person to take something

title: In Rerum Natura
body: In the nature of things; in the realm of actuality; in exlst-ence. In a dilatory plea, an allegatlon that the plaintiff is not in rerum natura is equlv-alent to averring that the person named is fictitious. 3 Bl. Comm. 301. In the clvll law the phrase is applied to things. Inst 2, 20, 7

title: In Separali
body: In several; in several-ty. Fleta, lib. 2, c. 54, 5 20

title: In Simili Materia
body: Dealing with the same or a kindred subject-matter

title: In Simplici Peregrinatione
body: In simple pilgrimage. Bract fob 338. A phrase in the old law of essoins. See Iir Generali Passaoio.

title: In Solido
body: In the civil law. For the whole; as a whole. An obligatlon in solido is one where each of the several obligors is liable for the whole; that is, it is joint and several. Henderson v. wadsworth, 115 U. S. 264, 6 Sop. Ct 140, 29 L. Ed. 377. Possession in aolidum is exclusive possession

title: In Solidum
body: For the whole. Si plures sint fldejussores, quotquot crunt nu-mero, singuli in solidum tcnentur, If there

title: In Solo
body: In the soil or ground. In solo alieno, in another’s ground. In solo proprio, in one’s own ground. 2 Steph. Comm. 20

title: In Specie
body: Specific; specifically. Thus, to decree performance in specie is to decree specific performance

title: In Statu Quo
body: In the condition in which it was. See Status Quo

title: In Stirpes
body: In the law of intestate succession. According to the roots or stocks; by representation; as distinguished from succession per capita. See Per Stirpes; Pbb Capita

title: In Subsidium
body: In aid

title: In Tantum
body: In so much; so much; so far; so greatly. Reg. orig. 97, 106

title: In Terminis Terminantibus
body: In

title: In Terrorem
body: In terror or warn-Ing; by way of threat. Applied to legacies given upon condition that the recipient shall not dlspute the validity or the dispositions of the will; such a condition being usually regarded as a mere threat

title: In Terrorem Populi
body: Lat. To the terror of the people. A technical phrase necessary in indictments for riots. 4 Car. A P. 373

title: In Testimonium
body: ■ Lat in witness; in evidence whereof

title: In Totidem Verbis
body: In so many words; in precisely the same words; word for word

title: In Toto
body: In the whole; wholly; com-pletely; as the award is void in toto

title: In Trajectu
body: In the passage over; on the voyage over. See Sir william Scott, 3 C. Rob. Adm. 141

title: In Transitu
body: In transit; on the way or passage; while passing from one person or place to another. 2 Kent, Comm. 540-552; More v. Lott. 13 Nev. 383; Amory Mfg. Co. v. Gulf, etc.. R. Co.. 89 Tex. 419, 37 S. W. 856. 59 Am. St. Rep. 65. On the voyage. 1 C. Rob. Adm. 338

title: In Vacuo
body: without object; without concomitants or coherence

title: In Vadio
body: In gage or pledge. 2 Bl. Comm. 157

title: In Ventre Sa Mere
body: L. Fr. In

title: In Vinculis
body: In chains; in actual custody. Gilb. Forum Rom. 97

title: In Viridi Observantia
body: Present to the minds of men, and in full force and operation

title: In Witness Whereof
body: The initial words of the concluding clause in deeds: “In witness whereof tbe said parties, have hereunto set their hands,” etc. A transla-tion of the Latin phrase “in cuj us rei testimonium

title: Inadequate
body: Insufficient; dlspropor-tlonate; lacking in effectiveness or in con-formity to a prescribed standard or measure

title: Inadmissible
body: That which, under the established rules of law, cannot be ad-mitted or received; e. g., parol evidence to contradict a written contract

title: Inadvertence
body: Heedlessness; lack of attention ; failure of a person to pay care-ful and prudent attention to the progress of a negotiation or a proceeding in court by which his rights may be affected. Used chiefly in statutory enumerations of the grounds on which a judgment or decree may be vacated or set aside; as, “mistake, inadvertence, surprise, or excusable neglect.” See Skinner v. Terry, 107 N. C. 103, 12 S. E. 118; Davis v. Steuben School Tp., 19 Ind. App. 694, 50 N. E. 1; Taylor v. Pope, 106 N. C. 267, 11 S. E. 257, 19 Am. St. Rep. 539; Thompson v. Connell, 31 or. 231, 48 Pnc. 467, 65 Am. St. Rep. 818

title: Inalienable
body: Not subject to alienation ; the characteristic of those things which cannot be bought or sold or transferred from one person to another, such as rivers and public highways, and certain personal rights; c. g., liberty

title: Inauguration
body: The act of install-lng or inducting into office with formal cere-monlee, as the coronation of a soverelgn, the inauguration of a presldent or governor, or the consecration of a prelate

title: Inblaura
body: In old records. Profit or product of ground. Cowell

title: Inboard
body: In maritime law, and particularly wlth reference to the stowage of cargo, thls term is contrasted with “out-board." It does not necessarily mean under deck, but is applied to a cargo so piled or stowed that.it does not project over tbe “board" (side or rail) of the vessel. See Al-len v. St Louis Ins. Co., 46 N. Y. Super. Ct 181

title: Inborh
body: In Saxon law. A security, pledge, or hypotheca, consisting of the chattels of a person unable to obtain a personal “borg,” or surety

title: Inbound Common
body: An unlnclosed

title: Incarceration
body: Imprisonment; confinement in a jail or penltentlary. This term is seldom used in law, though found occasionally in statutes, (Rev. St. okl. 1903, f 2068.) when so used, it appears always to mean confinement by competent public au-thority or under due legal process, wheresa “imprisonment” may be effected by a pri-. vate pcrson without warrant of law, and lf unjustifiable is called “false imprisonment” No occurrence of such a phrase as “false incarceration” bas been noted. See Imprisonment

title: Incastellare
body: To make a building serve as a castle. Jacob

title: Incendiary
body: A house-burner; one guilty of arson; one who maliciously and willfully sets another person’s building on fire

title: Inception
body: ON. Commencement; opening; initiation. The beginning .of. the operation of a contract or will, or of a note, mortgage, lien, etc.; the beginning of a cause or suit In court, oriental Hotel Co. v. Griffiths, 88 Tex. 574, 33 S. W. 652, 30 L. R. A. 765, 53 Am. St. Rep. 790; Sullivan ▼. Coal Co., 94 Tex. 541, 63 S. W. 307; Marvin v. McCul-lum, 20 Johns. (N. Y.) 288; State v- Bollero, 112 La. 850, 36 South. 754

title: Incest
body: The crime of sexual intercourse or cohabitation between a man and woman who are related to each other within the degrees wherein marriage is prohlblted by law. People v. Stratton, 141 Cal. 604, 75 Pac. 166; State v. Herges, 55 Minn. 464, 57 N. W. 205; Dinkey v. Com., 17 Pa. 129, 5o Am. Dec. 542; Taylor v. State, 110 Ga. 150, 35 S. E. 161

title: Inch
body: A measure of length, containing one-twelfth part of a foot; originally sup-posed equal to three barleycorns

title: Inchartare
body: RE. To give, or grant, and assure anything by a written instrument

title: Inchoate
body: Imperfect; unfinished; be-gun, but not completed; as a contract not executed by all the parties

title: Incident
body: This word, used as a noun, denotes anything which inseparably belongs to, or is connected with, or Inherent in, another thing, called the "principal.” In this sense, a court-baron is incident to a manor. Also, less strictly, it denotes anything which is usually connected with another, or connected for some purposes, though not insep-arably. Thus, the right of alienation is inci-dent to an estate in fee-simple, though sepa-rable in equity. See Cromwell v. Phipps (Sur.) 1N. Y. Supp. 278; Mount Carmel Fruit Co. v. webster, 140 Cal. 183, 73 Pae 826

title: Incidere
body: Lat in the civil and old English law. To fall into. Calvin

title: Incile
body: Lat. In the civil law. A trench. A place sunk by the side of a stream, so called because it is.cut (incidatur) Into or through the stone or earth. Dig. 43, 21, L 5. The term seems to have included ditches (fossae) and wells, (putei

title: Incineration
body: Burning to ashes; destruction of a substance by fire, as, the corpse of a murdered person

title: Incipitur
body: Lat. It is begun; it be-gins. In old practice, when the pleadings in an action at law, Instead of being recited at large on the issue-roll, were set out merely by thelr commencements, this was described as -entering the incipitur; i. e., the begin-ning

title: Incised Wound
body: In medical jurispru-dence. A cut or incision on a human body; a wound made by a cutting instrument, such as a razor. Burrill, Circ. Ev. 693; whart. & 8. Med. Jur. $ 808

title: Incite
body: To arouse; stir up; instigate; set iu motion; as, to "incite” a riot. Also, generally, in criminal law to instigate, per-suade, or move another to commit a crime; in this sense nearly synonymous with “abet* See Long v. State, 23 Neb. 33,36 N. W. 310

title: Incivile
body: Lat Irregular; improper; out of the due course of iaw

title: Incivism
body: Unfriendliness to the state or government of which one is a citizen

title: Inclausa
body: In old records. A home close or inclosure near the house. Paroch. Antiq. 31; Cowell

title: Inclose
body: To shut up. “To inclose a jury,” in Scotch practice, is to shut them up in a room by themselves. Bell. See Union Pac. Ry. Co. v. Harris, 28 Kan. 210; Camp-bell v. Gilbert, 57 Ala. 569

title: Inclosed Lands
body: Lands which are actually inclosed and surrounded with fences. Tapseil v. Crosskey, 7 Mees. & W. 446; Kim-ball v. Carter, 95 Va. 77, 2T S. E. 823, 38

title: Inclosure
body: In English law. Inclos-ure is the act of freeing land from rights of common, commonable rights, and generally all rights which obstruct cultivation and the productive employment of labor on the soil

title: Inclusive
body: Embraced; comprehend-ed; comprehending the stated limits or ex-tremes. opposed to “exclusive.”

title: Ingola
body: Lat in the civil law. An ln-habitant; a dweller or resident Properly, one who has transferred his domicile to any country

title: Ingome
body: The return in money from one’s business, labor, or capital invested; gains, profit, or private revenue. Braun’s Appeal, 105 Pa. 415; People v. Davenport, 30 Hun (N. Y.) 177; in re Slocum, 169 N. I. 153, 62 N. fl. 130; waring v. Savannah, 60 Ga. 99

title: Incommunication
body: In Spanish law. The condition of a prisoner who is not per-mitted to see or to speak with any person visiting him during his confinement A person accused cannot be subjected to this treatment unless it he expressly ordered by the judge, for some grave offense, and it cannot be continued for a longer period than is absolutely necessary. This precaution is re-sorted to for the purpose of preventing the accused from knowing beforehand the testimony of the witnesses, or from attempting to corrupt them and concert such measures ' as will efface the traces of hls guilt. As soon, thcrefore, as the danger of hls doing so has ceased, the interdiction ceases likewise. Escrlche

title: Incommutable
body: Not capable of or entitled to be commuted. See Commutation

title: Incompatible
body: Two or more rela-tious, offices, functions, or rights which can-not naturally, or may uot legally, exist in or be exercised by the same persou at the same time, are said to he incompatible. Thus, the relations of lessor and lessee of the same land, in one person at the same time, are ln-compatlble. So of trustee and beneficiary of the same property. See People v. Green, 46 How. Prac. (N. Y.) 170; Com. v. Sheriff. 4 Serg. & R. (Pa.) 276; Regents of University of Maryland v. williams, 9 Gill & J. (Md.) 422, 31 Am. Dec. 72

title: Incompetency
body: Lack of ability, le-gai qualification, or fitness to discharge the required duty. In re Leonard's Estate, 95 Mich. 295, 54 N. W. 1082; In re Cohn, 78 N. Y. 252; Stephenson v. Stephenson, 49 N. C. 473; Nehrling v. State, 112 wis. 637, 88 N. W. 610

title: Inconclusive
body: That which may be disproved or rebutted; not shutting out fur-ther proof or consideration. Applied to evi-dence and presumptions

title: Inconsistent
body: Mutually repugnant or contradictory; contrary, the one to the oth-er, so that both cannot stand, but the accept-ance or establishment of the one implies the abrogation or abandonment of the other; as, In speaking of “Inconsistent defenses,” or the repeal by a statute of “all laws inconsistent herewith." See In re Hickory Tree Road, 43 Pa. 142; Irwin v. Holbrook, 32 wash. 349, 73 Pac. 361; Swan v. U. S., 3 wyo. 151, 9 Pac. 931

title: Inconsulto
body: Lat. In the civil law. Unadvisedly; unintentionally. Dig. 28, 4, L

title: Incontinence
body: want of chastity; ln-dulgence in unlawful carnal connection. Lucas v. Nichols, 52 N. C. 35; State v. IIewlin, 128 N. C. 571, 37 S. E. 952

title: Inconvenience
body: In the rule that statutes should he so. construed as to avoid

title: Incopolitus
body: A proctor or vicar

title: Incorporamus
body: we incorporate, one of the words by which a corporation may be created in England. 1 Bl. Comm. 473; 8 Steph. Comm. .173

title: Incorporate
body: 1. To create a corpo-ration; to confer a corporate franchise upon determinate persons

title: Incorporation
body: 1. The act or pro-cess of forming or creating a corporation; the formation of a legal or political body, with the quality of perpetual existence and succession, unless limited by the act of incorporation

title: Incorporeal
body: without body; not of material nature; the opposite of “corporeal,” (q. v

title: Ingorrigible Rogue
body: A species of rogue or offender, described in the statutes 5 Geo. IV. c. 83, and 1 & 2 Vlct c. 38. 4 Steph. Comm. 309

title: Increase
body: E. (1) The produce of land; (SO the offspring of animals

title: Incrementum
body: Lat. Increase or im-provement, opposed to decrementum or abatement

title: Incriminate
body: To charge with crime; to expose to an accusation or charge of crime; to involve oneself or another in a criminal prosecution or the danger thereof; as, iu the rale that a witness is not bound to five testimony which would tend to incriminate him

title: Ingroachment
body: An unlawful gaining upon the right or possession of another. See Encboackment

title: Inculpate
body: To Impute blame or guilt; to accuse; to involve in guilt or crime

title: Ingulpatory
body: In the law of evidence. Going or tending to establish guilt; Intended to establish guilt; criminative. Burrill, Circ. Ev. 251, 252

title: Incumbent
body: A person who is in pres-ent possession of an office; one who is le-gally authorized to discharge the duties of an office. State v. McCoilister, 11 ohio, 50; gtate v. Blakemore, 104 Mo. 340, 15 S. W. 960.

title: Incumber
body: ER. To Incumber land is to piake it subject to a charge or liability; e. g., by mortgaging it Incumbrances include not only mortgages and other voluntary charges, but also liens, lites pendentes, registered judgments, and writs of execution, etc. Sweet. See Newhall v. Insurance Co., 52 Me. 181

title: Incumbrance
body: Any right to, or ln-terest in, land which may subsist in third persons, to the diminution of the value of the es-tate of the tenant, but consistently with the passing of the fee. Fitch v. Seymour, 9 Metc

title: Iis N
body: 467; Huyck v. Andrews, 118 N. Y. 81, 20 N. E. 581, 3 L. R. A. 789, 10 Am. St. Rep. 432; Alling v. Burlock, 46 Conn. 510; Demars v. Koehler, 62 N. J. Law, 203, 41 Atl. 720, 72 Am. St. Rep. 642; Lafferty v. Milligan, 1G5 Pa. 534, 30 Atl. 1030; Stambaugh v. .Smith, 23 ohio St 591

title: Incumbrancer
body: The holder of an incumbrance, e. g., a mortgage, on the estate of another. De Voe v. Rundle, 33 wash. 604, 74 Pac. 836; Shaeffer v. w’eed, 8 111. 514; Newhall v. Insurance Co., 52 Me. 181

title: Incur
body: Men contract debts; they incur liabilities. In the one case, they act attirma-tlvely; in the other, the liability is incurred or cast npon them by act or operation of law. “Incur” means something beyond contracts, —something not embraced in the word “debts.” Crandall v. Bryan, 5 Abb. Prac. (N. Y.) 169; Beekman v. Van Dolsen, 70 Hun, 288, 24 N. Y. Supp. 414; Ashe v. Young, 68 Tex. 123, 3 S. W. 454

title: Incurramentum
body: L. Lat The 11a-bility to a fine, penalty, or amercement. CowelL

title: Inde
body: Lat Thence; thenceforth; there* of; thereupon; for that cause

title: Indebitatus
body: Lat Indebted. Nun-quam indebitatus, never indebted. The title of the plea substituted in England for nil debet

title: Indebiti Solutio
body: Lat in the civ-il and Scotch law. A payment of what is not due. when made through lgnorance or by mistake, the amount paid might be re-covered back by an action termed “conditio indebiti” (Dig. 12, 6.) Bell

title: Indebitum
body: In the civil law. Not due or owing. (Dig. 12, 6.) Calvin

title: Indebtedness
body: The state of being in debt, without regard to the ability or ina-hility of the party to pay the same. See 1 Story, Eq. Jur. 343; 2 Hill, Abr. 421

title: Indecency
body: An act againBt good be-havior and a just delicacy. Timmons v. U

title: Indecimable
body: In old English law. That which is not tltheable, or liable to pay tithe. 2 Inst 490

title: Indefeasible
body: That whlch cannot be defeated, revoked, or made void. This term is usually applied to an estate or right which cannot be defeated

title: Indefensus
body: Lat. In old Engllsh practice. Undefended; undenied by pleading. A defendant who makes no defense er plea. Blount

title: Indefinite Failure Of Issue
body: UE

title: Indefinite Payment
body: In Scotch law. Payment without specification. In-definite payment is where a debtor, owing several debts to one creditor, makes a payment to the creditor, without specifying to which of the debts he means the payment to be applied. See Bell

title: Indemnificatus
body: Lat Indemnified. See Indemnify

title: Indemnify
body: To save harmless; to secure against loss or damage; to give security for the reimbursement of a person in case of an anticipated loss falling upon him

title: Indemnis
body: Lat. without hurt, harm, or damage; harmless

title: Indemnitee
body: The person who, in a contract of indemnity, is to be indemnified or protected by the other

title: Indemnitor
body: The person who is bound, by an indemnity contract, to indent nify or protect the other

title: Indemnity
body: An Indemnity is a col-lateral contract or assurance, by which one person engages to secure another against an anticipated loss or to prevent him from be-lng damnified by the legal consequences of an act or forbearance on the part of one of the parties or of some thlrd person. See Clv. Code CaL § 2772, Davis v. Phanlx Ins. Co., Ill Cal. 409, 43 Pac. 1115; Vandiver ▼. Poliak, 107 Ala. 547, 19 South. 180, 54 Am. St Rep. 118; Henderson-Achert Lithograph-lc Co. v. John ShlUlto Co., 64 ohlo SL 236, 60 N. E. 295, 83 Am. St Rep. 745. Thus, lnsurance is a contract of lndemnlty. So an Indemnifying bond is glven to a sheriff who fears to proceed under an execution where the property is claimed by a stranger

title: Indempnis
body: The old form of writing indemnis. Townsh. Pl. 19. So, indcmpni-flcatus for indemniflcatus

title: Indenization
body: The act of making a denizen, or of naturalizing

title: Indenture
body: A deed to which two or more persons are parties, and in whlch these enter lnto reclprocal and corresponding grants or obligations towards each other; whereas a deed-poll is properly one in which only the party making it executes lt, or binds hlmself by it as a deed, though the grantors or grantees thereln may be several in nnm-ber. 3 washb. Real Prop. 311; Scott v. Mills, 10 N. Y. St Rep. 358; Bowen v. Beck, 94 N. Y. 89, 46 Am. Rep. 124; Hopewell Tp. v. Am-well Tp., 6 N. J. Lnw, 175. See Indent, v

title: Independence
body: The state or condl-tlon of being free from dependence, subjection, or control. Polltlcal Independence is the attribute of a natlon or state which is entirely autonomous, and not subject to the government, control, or dlctation of any ex-terlor power

title: Independent
body: Not dependent; not subject to control, restriction, modification, or limitation from a glven outside source

title: Indeterminate
body: That which is un-certaln, or not particularly designated; as if I sell you one hundred bushels of wheat, without stating what wheat 1 Bouv. Inst, no. 950

title: Indians
body: The aboriginal lnhabitants of North America. Frazee v. Spokane Coun-ty, 29 wash. 278, 69 Pac. 782

title: Indicare
body: Lat. In the civil law. To show or discover. To fix or tell the price of a thing. Calvin. To inform against; to ac-cuse

title: Indicatif
body: An abolished writ by which a prosecution was in some cases removed from a court-christian to the queen’s bench. Enc. Lond

title: Indication
body: In the lnw of evidence. A sign or token; a fact pointing to some ln-ference or conclusion. Burrill, Circ. Ev. 251, 252, 263, 275

title: Indicative Evidence
body: This is not evidence properly so called, but the mere sug-gestion of evidence proper, which may possibly be procured if the suggestion is follow-ed up. Brown

title: Indicavit
body: In English practice. A writ of prohibition that lies for a patron of a church, whose clerk is sued in the spiritual court by the clerk of another patron, for tithes amounting to a fourth part of the value of the living. 3 Bl. Coinm. 91; 3 Steph. Comm. 711. So termed from the em-phatlc word of the Latin form. Reg. orlg. 35b, 36

title: Indicia
body: Signs; indications. Circum-stances which point to the existence of a

title: Indicium
body: In the civil law. A slgn or mark. A species of proof, answering very nearly to the circumstantial evidence of the common law. Best, Pres. p. 13, | 11, note; wills, Circ. Ev. 34

title: Indict
body: See Iwdictmbwt

title: Indictable
body: Proper or necessary to be prosecuted by process of indictment

title: Indicted
body: Charged in an indictment with a criminal offense. See Indictment

title: Indictee
body: A person indicted

title: Indictio
body: In old public law. A declaration; a proclamation. Indictio belli, a declaration or lndiction of war. An indict-ment

title: Indiction, Cycle Of
body: A mode of computing time by the space of fifteen years, instituted by Constantine the Great; origl-nally the period for the payment of certain taxes. Some of the charters of King Edgar and Henry III. are dated by lndictlons. wharton

title: Indictment
body: An indictment is an ac-cusation in writing found and presented by a grand jury, legally convoked and sworn, to the court in which it is impaneled, charg-ing that a person therein named has done some act, or been guilty of some omission, which, by law, is a publlc offense, punishable on indictment. Code Iowa 1880, | 4295; Pen. Code Cal. 8 917; Code Ala. 1886, | 4364. And see Grin v. Shine, 187 U. 8. 181, 23 Sup. Ct 98, 47 L. Ed. 130; State v. walker, 32 N. G 236; Ex parte Hart, 63 Fed. 259, 11 C. C. A. 165, 28 L. R. A. 801; Ex parte Bain, 121 U. S. 1, 7 Sup. Ct 781, 30 L. Ed. 849; Ex parte Slater, 72 Mo. 102; Finley v. State, 61 Ala. 201

title: Indifferent
body: Impartial; unbiased; disinterested. People v. Vermllyea, 7 Cow. (N. Y.) 122; Fox v. Hills, 1 Conn. 307

title: Indigena
body: In old English law. A sub-ject born; one born withln the realm, or naturalized by act of parliament Co. Litt 8a. The opposite of “al/cnigena," (q. v

title: Indigent
body: In a general sense an “in-digent” person is one who Is'needy and poor, or one who has not suflicient property to fur-nlsh him a living nor any one able to support him and to whom he is entitled to look for support. See Storrs Agricultural School v. Whitney, 54 Conn. 342, 8 Atl. 141; Juneau County v. wood County, 109 wis. 330, 85 N. W. 387; City of Lynchburg v. Slaughter, 75 Va. 62. The laws of some of the states dis-tinguish between “panpers” and “indigent persons," the latter heing persons who have no property or source of Income sufficient for their support aside from their own labor, though self-supporting when able to work ahd in employment. See In re Hybart, 119 N. C. 359, 25 S. E. 963; People v. Schoharie County, 121 N. Y. 345, 24 N. E. 830; Rev. St Mo. 1899, { 4894 (Am. SL 1906, p. 2616

title: Indignity
body: In the law of divorce, a specles of cruelty addressed to the mind, sen-slbllities, self-respect, or personal honor of the subject, rather than to tlie body, aud de-flned as “unmerited contemptuous conduct towards another; any action towards au-other which manifests contempt for him; contumely, incivility, or injury accompanied with insult.” Coble v. Coble. 55 N. C. 395; Erwin v. Erwin, 57 N. C. 84; Hooper v. Hooi>er, 19 Mo. 357; Goodman v. Goodman, 80 Mo. App. 281; 1 Bish. Mar. & Div. 8 826. Bat the phrase “indignities to the person,” as used in statutes, has reference to bodily indignities, as distinguished from Ruch as may be offered to the mind, sensibilities, or

title: Indirect
body: A term almost always used in law in opposition to “direct,” though not the only antithesis of the latter word, as the terms “collateral" and “cross” are sometimes used in contrast with “direct”

title: Indispensable
body: That which cannot be spared, omitted, or dispensed with

title: Indistanter
body: Forthwith; without delay

title: Inditee
body: L. Fr. In old English law. A person indicted. Mirr. c. 1, J 3; 9 Coke, pref

title: Individual
body: As a noun, this term de-notes a single person as distinguished from a group or class, and also, very commonly, a private or natural person as distinguished from a partnership, corporation, or associa-tion; but it is said that this restrictive slgni-flcation is not necessarily Inherent in the word, and that it may, in proper cases, in-clude artificial persons. See Bank of U. 8. v. State, 12 Smedes & M. (Miss.) 460; State v. Bell Telephone Co., 36 ohio St 310, 38 Am. Rep. 583; Pennsylvania R. Co. v. Canal Com’rs, 21 Pa. 20. As an adjective, “Indivld-ual” means pertaining or belonging to, or characteristic of, one single person, either in opposition to a firm, association, or corpora-tion, or considered in his relation thereto

title: Individuum
body: Lat in the civil law

title: Indivisible
body: Not susceptlbie of dl-vision or apportionment; inseparable; eh

title: Indivistjm
body: Lat. That which two or more persons hold in common without par-tition; undivided.

title: Indorsat
body: In old Scotch law. In-dorsed. 2 Pitc. Crim. Tr. 41

title: Indorsee
body: The persou to whom a bill of exchange, promissory note, bill of lad-Ing, etc., is assijned by indorsement, giving him a right to sue thereon

title: Indorsement
body: The act of a payee, drawee, accommodation Indorser, or holder . of a bill, note, check, or other negotiable to-strnment, in writing his name upon the back of the same, with or without further or qual-ifying words, whereby the property In the same is assigned and transferred to another

title: Indorser
body: He who indorses; i. e., being the payee or holder, writes his name on the back of a bill of exchange, etc.

title: Indubitable Proof
body: Evidence which is not only found credible, but is of such weight and directness as to make ont the facts alleged beyond a doubt. Hart v. Carroll, 85 Pa. 511; Jermyn v. McClure, 195 Pa. 245, 45 Atl. 938

title: Inducement
body: In oontraots. The

title: Induces
body: In international law. A

title: Inductio
body: Lat in the civU law. obliteration, by drawing the pen or stylus over the writing. Dig. 28, 4; Calvin

title: Induction
body: In ecclesiastical law. In-duction is the ceremony by which an incum-bent who has been instituted to a benefice is vested with full possession of all the profits belonging to the church, so tiiat he becomes seised of the temporalities of the church, and is theu complete incumbent. It is performed by virtue of a mandate of in* duction directed by the bishop to the archdeacon, who either perforins it in person, or directs his precept to one or more other clergymen to do it Phillim. Ecc. Law, 477

title: Indulgence
body: In the Roman Catholic Church. A remission of the punishment due to sins, granted hy the pope or church, nnd supposed to save tlie sinner from purgatory. Its abuse led to the Reformation in Germany. wharton. Forbearance, (q. v

title: Indulto
body: In ecclesiastical law. A

title: Indument
body: Endowment, (q. v

title: Industrial And Provident So-Cieties
body: Societies formed in England for carrying on any labor, trade, or handicraft, whether wholesale or retail, including the buying and selling of land and also (but suh-ject to certain restrictions) the business of banking

title: Industrial Sghools
body: Schools (es-tablished by voluntary contribution) in which Industrial training is provided, aud in which children are lodged, dothed, and fed, as well as taught

title: Industriam, Per
body: Lat. A qualified property in animals ferae natura may be ac-quired per industriam, i. e., by a man’s reclaiming and making them tame by art, in-dustry, and education; or by so confining them wlthln his own immediate power that they cannot escape and'use their natural liberty. 2 Steph. Comm. 5

title: Inebriate
body: A person addicted to the use of intoxicating liquors; an habitual drunkard

title: Ineligibility
